heading.title: PART 20 RESOLUTION OF PROCEEDINGS WITHOUT HEARING [rr 20.1–20.34]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 20 RESOLUTION OF PROCEEDINGS WITHOUT HEARING [rr 20.1–20.34]

row.entry: These rules permit directions regulating the conduct of mediations ordered under CPA s 26 and conditionally require parties to complete mediation within 28 days.

This Division outlines the procedural requirements relating to, and excludes certain proceedings from, arbitrations ordered under CPA s 38 . It also outlines the procedures concerning rehearings under CPA ss 42–47 .

These rules permit reference of proceedings for report by a referee. They contain the procedure for appointing referees and permit directions regulating the conduct of the referred proceedings. The rules regulate the content of referees' reports and their adoption by the court.

These rules govern the form of offers of compromise and the manner and time of their acceptance. They also regulate the withdrawal and enforcement of acceptance of offers. The rules restrict disclosure of without prejudice offers, except in the circumstances specified in r 20.30(3).
This rule permits the parties to obtain judgment by agreement. It precludes consensual declarations of right and attempts to restrict disclosure of judgments and orders.

entry.emph: Division 5 — Acknowledgment of liquidated claim — Rule 20.33

row.entry: This rule permits a defendant to admit the whole amount of a liquidated claim.
This rule permits a defendant to admit the whole of a liquidated claim instead of filing a defence. The rule entitles the plaintiff to judgment on the admission.

In this Part, Div 4 does not apply to class 1, 2 and 3 proceedings in the Land and Environment Court. Divisions 5 , 6 and 7 do not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division. Part 20 does not apply to the Industrial Court except for Div 4 (Div 4 does not apply until after conciliation has been attempted under s 109 of the Industrial Relations Act 1996) or to the Industrial Relations Commission: UCPR Sch 1. Apart from those exclusions the Part applies to all courts in CPA Sch 1 : see r 1.5 and Sch 1 . In the Dust Diseases Tribunal special offers of compromise provisions are contained in Pt 6 of the Dust Diseases Tribunal Regulation and take priority over the rules: see reg 70.

The Part combines a number of provisions from the former SCR Pts 22, 72, 72B and 72C. Similar provisions existed in the DCR Pts 19A, 28B and 51A and LCR Pts 17A and 38. The rules modify some aspects of the offer of compromise procedure concerning the ability to make open offers, and the time for acceptance where the offer is made less than two months before the hearing.
Adoption, variation or rejection of the report ‥ [20.24.5]
Appeal from adoption or rejection of report ‥ [20.24.10]
— Decline or failure by arbitrator to hear and determine proceedings ‥ [r 20.9]
Entry of judgment in accordance with accepted offer ‥ [20.27.7]
Evidence of the proceedings before the referee ‥ [20.24.15]
— Times for appointment, completion and report ‥ [r 20.4] , [r 20.5] , [r 20.7] , [r 20.7.5]
— Disclosure of without prejudice offers, restriction against ‥ [r 20.30]
— Failure to comply with accepted offer ‥ [r 20.29]
Point of law not raised before the referee ‥ [20.24.35]
Reasonableness of the time for acceptance ‥ [20.26.40]
— Directions to relating to the reference ‥ [r 20.17] , [r 20.19] , [r 20.20] , [r 20.21]
— Report of referee, form and adoption ‥ [r 20.23] , [r 20.24]

p.text: This Division applies to matters referred to mediation under Part 4 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005.
The court may give directions regulating the practice and procedure to be followed in a mediation, including the preparation and service of documents.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.3] r 20.3 Statements as to proposed referral to mediation (cf SCR Part 72C, rule 2; Act No 9 1973, section 164A; Act No 11 1970, section 21L)

leg:heading.title: Statements as to proposed referral to mediation (cf SCR Part 72C, rule 2; Act No 9 1973, section 164A; Act No 11 1970, section 21L)

p.text: On any occasion that proceedings are before the court for directions, the court may require each active party to state any of the following:
whether the party consents to referral of a matter arising in the proceedings for mediation,
whether the parties agree as to who is to be the mediator,
whether the parties agree as to the proportions in which the costs of mediation are to be borne, and the terms of any such agreement.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.4] r 20.4 Appointments by mediator (cf SCR Part 72C, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Appointments by mediator (cf SCR Part 72C, rule 3)

p.text: Within 7 days after being notified that a matter has been referred for mediation, the mediator to whom the matter is referred must appoint a time for the mediation and notify the parties, in writing, of the time appointed.
The mediator may also appoint a time for a preliminary meeting of the parties.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.5] r 20.5 Completion of mediation (cf SCR Part 72C, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Completion of mediation (cf SCR Part 72C, rule 4)

p.text: The parties and the mediator must conduct the mediation with the object, so far as practicable, of completing the mediation within 28 days.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 20.6] r 20.6 Mediation session procedure (cf SCR Part 72C, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Mediation session procedure (cf SCR Part 72C, rule 6)

p.text: The following provisions apply to the conduct of a mediation session unless the mediator, or the court, otherwise directs:
the session must be attended:
subject to subparagraph (ii), by each party or, if a party is a corporation, by an officer of the corporation having authority to settle the proceedings, or
if the conduct of the proceedings by a party is controlled by an insurer, by an officer of the insurer having authority to settle the proceedings,
a party may be accompanied by that party’s barrister or solicitor at the session.
A person who is required by subrule (1)(a) to attend a mediation session may do so by telephone, video link or other form of communication, but only with the leave of the court or the mediator.
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 23 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 7 November 2008]
Within 7 days after the conclusion of the last mediation session, the mediator must advise the court of the following:
the time and date the first mediation session commenced, and
the time and date the last mediation session concluded.
[r 20.7 subst Amendment 24 of 2009 r 2 and Sch 1[11], effective 6 March 2009]
Legislation cited in [20.7.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 Pt 4, s 30(4).

Notification in accordance with the present rule complements the mediation confidentiality provisions in CPA s 30(4) . Under that sub-section conduct at, and documents prepared for, or as the result of, a mediation under Civil Procedure Act Pt 4 are inadmissible . Timely notification by the mediator may provide an important measure of certainty in relation to the admissibility of correspondence between the parties: Sharjade Pty Ltd v RAAF (Landings) Ex-Servicemen Charitable Fund Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1347; BC200811357 (no notification of end of mediation session, subsequent emailed Calderbank offer rejected on the basis that it was a document prepared in the course of and/or “as a result of” a mediation session).
